title: Giannis Antetokounmpo vs. The World (and Team USA)
text:
There are few people who will be watching the FIBA World Cup game between the U.S. and Greece this weekend as carefully as Geoffrey Pyatt. He is personally invested in the success of both countries. In fact, that’s his job. Geoffrey Pyatt is the U.S. ambassador to Greece.

“Giannis is probably the biggest thing that’s happening these days in U.S.-Greece relations,” Pyatt said of Giannis Antetokounmpo, the Greek star of the Milwaukee Bucks. “So it’ll be interesting how that plays out.”

It will also be interesting because Team USA hasn’t been this vulnerable since 2006, the last time they lost a game in the Olympics or World Cup. The country that beat them? It was Greece. That loss came on the heels of the U.S. turning a bronze medal in 2004 into a national humiliation. The country that hosted those Olympics? It was also Greece.

But this ominous history is not the reason Greece vs. the U.S. on Saturday morning will be so interesting. The real intrigue here isn’t about things that have happened before. It exists because of something that’s never happened before: The best player is not playing for Team USA.

That’s why Greece vs. the U.S. could be the most compelling matchup of this tournament. It’s the NBA’s most valuable player against a team of NBA players. It’s also the closest thing to Giannis Antetokounmpo against the world as this world might ever see.

That it’s even happening in the first place is a historical anomaly. Antetokounmpo is the first reigning MVP to challenge Team USA with teammates who give him a legitimate chance to win. FIBA basketball is more like the NCAA tournament than the NBA. The games are physical, intense and often unpredictable. And it’s extraordinarily useful to have the best player on the floor.

His team isn’t the betting favorite to beat the U.S. (Serbia) or the country that has come torturously close to upsetting the Americans (Spain), but it would surprise absolutely nobody if Greece became the first country to beat Team USA on a stage like this since Greece.

Greece's Giannis Antetokounmpo, center, tries to handle the ball through Brazil's Alex Garcia and Vitor Benite. Photo: wang zhao/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

It would also be a monumental achievement for Antetokounmpo. The only other Greek player on an NBA roster is Thanasis Antetokounmpo, his brother, and he’s spent the last two seasons playing for Panathinaikos in Athens, where his coach, Rick Pitino, had more NBA experience than his teammates. But the presence of Giannis Antetokounmpo alone might be enough. That’s because every player on the team, even the ones who are not members of the Antetokounmpo family, benefit from his transcendence.

The best way to understand his effect may be to think about Antetokounmpo as if he is a condiment. He is the tzatziki of basketball.

“Giannis is like this secret sauce that gets added to the Greek squad and they all play better,” Pyatt said.

Greece also lost this week to a Brazil team starring Anderson Varejao and Leandro Barbosa, which was not the most encouraging outcome, considering Varejao and Barbosa washed out of the NBA two years ago. Antetokounmpo took only one shot in the fourth quarter. This felt like roughly a billion shots too few. Things got so bleak for the Greeks that Brazil’s coach bragged about stopping the world’s most unstoppable player after the game and claimed that someone named Alex Garcia had “kicked his ass.” Alex Garcia is 39 years old and played his last NBA game in 2004.

But there are two sides to every upset. This one would be as much about Greece as the U.S.

Giannis Antetokounmp of Greece reacts during a match against the Dominican Republic. Photo: Li Bo/Xinhua/Zuma Press

For nearly three decades, ever since Team USA started using NBA players, international basketball tournaments have been an exercise in American exceptionalism. But the basketball world isn’t the same as it was in 1992 when the Dream Team swaggered its way to global domination. It’s flatter. The Americans lost in 2002, 2004 and 2006, and they were challenged despite winning the 2008, 2012 and 2016 Olympics. They can’t assume every competition will be a piece of cake or else they’ll find themselves eating a large heaping of crow.

But even the national teams that make them sweat are typically built around generations of players who’d been together since they were kids—not a singular force like Antetokounmpo. Team USA always had the most talent and the most talented player. Except that won’t be true on Saturday. The Americans are no longer so American. This particular Team US is defined by who’s not playing: LeBron James, Stephen Curry, Kevin Durant, James Harden, Kawhi Leonard, Paul George, Damian Lillard and Kyrie Irving are still enjoying their summer vacations.

The Americans still have an enviable collection of starpower, the World Cup’s deepest roster and the tournament’s two best guards in Kemba Walker and Donovan Mitchell, but there was cause for concern even before they learned Jayson Tatum wouldn’t play against Greece with a sprained ankle. They had won 78 consecutive international games heading until they lost an exhibition to Australia last month, and they would have lost to Turkey this week if Turkey hadn’t picked the last 10 seconds of a one-point game in overtime as the right time to miss four straight free throws.

Which brings us to this peculiar matchup between a favorite that’s oddly susceptible and an underdog with an improbable advantage.

The only other time the U.S. and Greece could play again is if they meet in the World Cup finals—this is still pool play, not the knockout round, so a loss won’t eliminate either team—but there are some people in Athens who aren’t taking any chances. At the beginning of last week, there were already plans to screen the game in the U.S. embassy. It won’t be the first time that Antetokounmpo makes an appearance there. He visited this summer with his mother and brothers. “He insisted on coming in, waiting in line and going through the security protocols just like everybody else,” Pyatt said.

Now the Greeks are banking on Antetokounmpo doing some of the things that nobody else can do. But whether that will be enough to beat the U.S. was not something that Pyatt was willing to predict.

“That’s a diplomatic challenge,” the ambassador said. “The best team will win.”

description: Greece has a chance to upset the U.S. in the FIBA World Cup. Why? Because the best player on the court won’t be American.
